dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, big news hitting the wires today from Kaspi.kz. Sounds like a pretty major strategic shift for them, uh, internationally.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Joint Stock Company Kaspi.kz (Kaspi.kz) (Nasdaq: KSPI), which operates the Kaspi.kz Super App for consumers and Kaspi Pay Super App for merchants, today announces a new partnership with Alipay + to enable Kaspi.kz customers to pay using the Kaspi.kz Super App and QR code, throughout China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, absolutely. They've officially announced they're pulling the plug on their partnership with Alipay+. [overlaps] Which, you know, was a big deal.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Joint Stock Company Kaspi.kz (Kaspi.kz) ... today announces a new partnership with Alipay + to enable Kaspi.kz customers to pay using the Kaspi.kz Super App and QR code, throughout China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right? I thought that was supposed to be their big push into, like, international payments, especially for folks traveling to China. What, um, what happened?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? I thought that was supposed to be their big push into, like, international payments, especially for folks traveling to China. What, um, what happened?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When travelling in China, Kazakhstanis no longer need to take cash or a card with them. Now, using the Kaspi.kz Super App, purchases in Chinese stores, cafes, taxis and more than 80 million points throughout China can be paid for by QR code.

dialogue_turns.text: Well, turns out their pilot program for the Kaspi.kz Super App in China was, uh, deemed "unsuccessful." Apparently, the whole QR code payment system was pretty cumbersome.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Cumbersome? Like, just difficult to use?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Cumbersome? Like, just difficult to use?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and not just that. They had frequent outages. So, you can imagine, customer dissatisfaction just, like, shot right up. Transactions plummeted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and not just that. They had frequent outages. So, you can imagine, customer dissatisfaction just, like, shot right up. Transactions plummeted.

dialogue_turns.text: So that original goal they had, you know, facilitating payments in over 80 million points across China, that just never materialized, did it?

dialogue_turns.text: Nope. Totally missed that mark. Mikhail Lomtadze, the CEO and co-founder, he, um, he sounded pretty disappointed in his statement.

We are happy to announce, that in partnership with AliPay+, we have launched a new service.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I read that. He said the "reality has fallen far short." That's pretty blunt for a CEO. He also mentioned "insurmountable" technical issues.

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And he explicitly said the Kaspi.kz Super App's capabilities were "insufficient for international applications." Ouch.

dialogue_turns.text: But then you have Alipay+â€™s side, right? Venetia Lee from Ant International, she seemed a bit, uh, surprised by this.

dialogue_turns.text: So, for Kaspi.kz customers, what does this mean when they're traveling to China now? No more using the Super App for payments, I guess.

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's back to basics. They're advising customers to, uh, use cash or cards.

dialogue_turns.text: And this seems to be part of a bigger pivot for Kaspi.kz as a whole, doesn't it? Like, away from these ambitious digital payment services.
